library.Library_Story__c: Truly Living Well is an urban farm that uses quality local food production to connect people to their food and the land, creating better communities through education, economic development and environmental improvement. There are summer camps that attract many children and a weekly farmers market that brings families to the farm for fresh just picked produce. A perfect place for a Little Free Library!

My daughter and I took some scrap materials we had around the house and from a demolition down the street and built this Little Free Monster Library.  The paint is leftover from repainting the basement and the roof shingles are made of cut up aluminum soda cans.

Full construction story at:
http://journal.electric-rocket.com/?p=2119

The St. Pius X Catholic High School is proud to be the steward of a Little Free Library.  Our LFL is a gift from the students to our community:  painted by the Art Club, promotional materials translated by our AP Spanish class, book drive organized by our Green Club, and inspirational bookmarks created by out Helping Hands Club.

We live in the wonderful Atlanta, Georgia neighborhood of Virginia Highland and have a plethora of children living here. My husband and I have seen other LFL's scattered about the area and felt, with all the children and adults, our street would be a great location for a LFL. 
After erecting it in our front yard, I sent an email to our surrounding neighbors and the support and encouraging words have been awesome! 
Our Little Free Library is a welcome addition to our little corner of the world.

I had been wanting to build a Little Free Library  for my church. But first I had  to find just the right door and build the library around it. I hit all the antique and second hand shops near my home, but found nothing that inspired me until one weekend I went to visit my cousins in Ohio and we took a trip to Waynesville, Ohio. I walked into the first shop and there was the door I had been searching for all these months. I paid $15 for it and took it back home to start the project.

From the idea to its realization, it took a long time ... For some reason hubby didn't want to create a 'door' ... So I went door-chasing and instead, fell in love with this antique cabinet at a local flea market.  Hubby spent hours stripping it, removing the 'mirror' film on its door, sanding and clear-staining it ... As it was not deep enough, he added some extra depth.  The roof was another complicated story ... At the end, we managed to have it matchung our house.
This library is dedicated to my grandmother whose love of books and literature shaped my life and blessed my future.  Make time for reading...

This Little Free Library site is sponsored by Mixed Media Melange and is part of a network of libraries being installed for the benefit of our area low income children. The program is the handiwork of the Cross Keys Foundation, Inc (www.CrossKeysFoundation.org) and is made possible by the Atlanta Braves Foundation, The Awesome Foundation, The Briarwood Park Conservancy, The Ashford Park School Foundation, Brookhaven Storage, Mr. Houston Feaster, Mr. & Mrs. Joe and Eileen Gebbia, The Brookhaven Rotary, Mr. Chad Boles, and Around Brookhaven.

I created this library in honor of my mother Claudine Moore Walker. She was an educator who taught elementary school children in the Memphis City Schools for 26 years. After retiring she worked with the Literacy Mid-South to help teach illiterate adults to read. She was an avid reader as well. I finished the library today as it would have been her 78th birthday and it marks her passing three months ago today to Leukemia. The library will be located in our front yard garden in a little four street neighborhood. We have a lot of people who walk through the neighborhood with their dogs and children and I hope that it will be a great addition to our community. (Of course we are about to be deluged with rain today so I donâ??t want to add books and official open the library until that passes but I did want to make sure the library was registered on April 4th. Thank you.)

This is the 3rd LFL in Historic College Park, Ga! A friend asked me (Kimy Kennedy) who has the 2nd LFL in our n'hood if I would put one in front of my house --- I said of course! LOVE IT! The guy who build our first LFL also built mine and Kimy's.
Our library was placed in a park next to a pavilion dedicated to a beloved neighbor.
library.Street__c:
Louise G. Howard Park
Collier Road at Overbrook Drive

library.Library_Story__c: We now have SIX of these in your neighborhood (Historic College Park). We wanted to surprise the Mayeske's with a Dr. Suess type LFL --- Russell builds these and I register them. It's spreading magic ONE book at a time. You never know when someone will read a book and it will change their path, way of thinking or just add joy to their lives. WE LOVE OUR LITTLE FREE LIBRARIES! xxoooo
This Little Free Library was a way for me to give back to my old elementary school as my Eagle Scout Service project
Ours is Dr. Seuss themed since all of our children loved his books when they were little.
My friend Mara helped me build the library. It was the first time either of us had made something like this so it was an adventure in trial by error.

library.Library_Name__c: Pat and Peter Jenkins #12214 Atlanta GA

library.Library_Story__c: Ode to the Mystery on Pinetree Drive ~Debby Miller May 2012 . . . 1. A dollhouse, outgrown and discarded, From Burlington to Pinetree was carted. Intended to be A library free, Right away, the new owner got started. 2. It would be the best birthday gift ever. His wife would so love the endeavor. Heâ??d build a new roof, Add a door, waterproof, To keep her books safe from the weather. Six months later, the unimproved dollhouse was still in the garage . . . 3. Alas, the great plan had a hole. For his schedule was out of control. Too soon came the date. Her gift would be late. But at least he could mount it on pole. So, in November 2012, on the eve of her birthday . . . 4. He worked by the light of the moon. It was worth it to hear her croon. â??A Little Free Library? A gift extraordinary! And I know you will finish it soon.â?? 5. But the weeks, they came and they went. His time by his job was well-spent. Then one day sublime, In the fullness of time, A small change became evident. By now it was January 2013 . . . 6. Firstâ??a tiny table and chair. The mystery was, â??Who put it there?â?? We questioned our friends. All leads were dead-ends. So, how did it come, and from where? 7. Soon a miniature cupboard appeared. Still, nobody volunteered. More pieces showed up, Nobody fessed up, But at each new arrival, we cheered. 8. A fireplace, a bed, and a stove, Pieces tucked into every alcove. A bunny, if you please, And a pet Siamese, Became part of the treasury trove. 9. An easel with original art! A piano for performing Mozart! You were ever so clever. We kept hoping, however, That your secret you soon would impart. 10. One morning the windows had curtains. We had to find out now, for certain. Your ID, kept hazy, Is driving us crazy! How long can you keep up this flirtinâ??? One piece at a time, across seven months . . . 11. Your wit simply canâ??t be outdone. Your game was tremendously fun. From unfinished small house, To fu

This unit is at Woodward Elementary, the poorest school in DeKalb County, GA as measured by the Title I/FRL rate of 99.5%. It is one of a series of LFLs being installed and maintained by the Cross Keys Foundation in its unique program targeting young readers in at risk populations. This site was made possible by Joe & Eileen Gebbia, the Atlanta Braves Foundation, Brookhaven Self Storage, and Houston Feaster. These monuments to early childhood reading are cropping up all over Cross Keys community as testimony to our commitment to educating our children! See http://tinyurl.com/bookhaven for program details.

This library is dedicated to the children of the Boys and Girls Club - Brookhaven Branch. It is one of a network of libraries the Cross Keys Foundation is setting up as monuments to the importance of early childhood reading. The site is made possible thanks to Joe & Eileen Gebbia, the Atlanta Braves Foundation, Brookhaven Self Storage, and Girl Scout Troop 1927. These monuments to early childhood reading are cropping up all over Cross Keys community as testimony to our commitment to educating our children! See http://tinyurl.com/bookhaven for program details.

Built in honor of David Burt, founder of Hapeville Arts Alliance and the Arts Center in Hapeville. The library is a replica of the Arts Alliance, a historic home in the City of Hapeville. (NOTE: photos sent in another email with LFL number for identification)
This Library was built and is sponsored by Lost in the Stacks (http://www.wrek.org/lostinthestacks/), a weekly library rock 'n roll radio show that airs every Friday at noon on 91.1 FM, WREK Atlanta.

library.Street__c:
1122 Woodland Ave. SE, Atlanta, GA 30316
1122 Woodland Ave. SE

library.Library_Story__c: This is actually our SECOND LFL -- our first is right around the corner from this one. This LFL is called Lemongrass Cottage LFL -- it sits in front of my rental house. My rental house (Lemongrass cottage) has become a haven thus far for recently single moms. I thought what a WONDERFUL way to make it a magical place to live than to have a LFL out front! This particular LFL has a special 'attic room' that I can change the scenery --- this month (Oct) has skeletons that bobble back and forth. I'll change it out for the seasons. It has a stained glass window as well in the attic room. It's a WONDERFUL addition to Rugby Ave in Historic College Park.
This was the best Christmas present ever!

library.Library_Name__c: carol and Bob Kleemeier #617 Atlanta Georgia
Eric & Jennifer Van Fossen #10683 Atlanta GA

library.Library_Story__c: Our library is the first of a dozen or so planned for our community by the Cross Keys Foundation, Inc. The network of LFLs are focusing on reaching young readers from our lower income and primarily immigrant populations. We are partnering with the Atlanta Braves Foundation and local business to realize the network using the LFL concept. Name listed on map should be, "Cross Keys Foundation"

This is the Little Free Library hosted by the Milam Circle community in Clarkston/Decatur, GA. Materials for the library were donated by residents in the community and construction was completed by David Stevenson.

library.Street__c:
Harold Avenue Green Space
595 Harold Ave. NE

library.Library_Story__c: Handpainted by my husband with some of our neighborhood's feathered residents! (I don't think they read, though.)

While out walking our dogs one night, the kids and I(Ellie 10, Sam 7) saw a free little library in the neighborhood which the kids began frequenting regularly. They were inspired and decided that we needed one too so the neighborhood kids can trade books. One 98 degree day of labor,(The kids helped mix the cement for the post base) some wood and some nails and TA-DA....A new neighborhood free little library!

Echo Lake Class, the 3 and 4-year old class at Turning Sun School, spent the year reading books, making paper, exploring old typewriters, writing books, illustrating books, visiting college libraries, and visiting Little Free Libraries around our East Lake neighborhood. We decided to build our own! Each child designed a Little Free Library. They made drawings and 3D models. Finally, we held a school-wide vote. The winning design was a rocket-ship library. The children wanted it to be a kids-only library that they could reach. A class dad generously volunteered to build the library for us. He surprised us with something spectacular! We honored the children's work by stenciling their blueprints onto the rocket ship. Building the library was a meaningful way for the children to engage with their community and to leave a lasting legacy at Turning Sun School and East Lake.

We were inspired to build our LFL by a friend and decided that while we were building one we might as well build three. We kept one, gave one to the friend that inspired us, and gave the other to a family member who had been wanting an LFL of her own. We personalized ours by adding a box for dog treats to give our canine neighbors something to be excited about, too.

library.Library_Name__c: Imran Siddiqui #18738 1410 Ponce De Leon Avenue Northeast GA
library.Library_Story__c: The people of St. John's Lutheran Church decided to construct a Little Free Library in order to share the love of God in our community and among our neighbors, through the gift of reading.

My adult children gave me a Little Free Library for my birthday.  It is the best gift I have ever received.  For 25 years of my career I was a Librarian/Media Specialist.  Sharing books is at the core of my heart.  We have at least 3 visitors every day and have received thank you notes, new books, and returned books.  It is the best way to spread the love of reading to all.
Located in front of Cross Keys High School. Typically both English and Spanish language books are available.

I had been wanting to build a Little Library for years.  One day it dawned on me that I had an old newspaper rack in the crawlspace serving as a storage space for some gardening tools.  I decided I could  convert it into a spacious Little Library without actually having to cut wood. In case you're curious, I got the rack at a yard sale about a decade ago because I thought it was kind of cool.

Fred Armon Toomer Elementary School's community partner The Temple built installed and decorated 3 LFLs during their annual community service project on Mitzvah Day Sunday October 21 2012 for our entire school community. Everyone is invited to participate in our school community's book exchange and share the love of reading regardless if you are a Toomer Cougar Kirkwood Eastlake resident business owner or visiting the area. We appreciate everyone for helping us take care of our 3 LFLs and pay it forward by giving taking and sharing books for babies children and adults to enjoy from any genre. Our students are encouraged to visit the 3 LFLs with their teachers and families as often as possible. Thank you to everyone in the Kirkwood East Lake and any participating community business or civic group for helping us spread skills creativity and wisdom with our PreK through 5th grade students and across generations.
library.Street__c:
Fred Armon Toomer Elementary School
65 Rogers Street, NE

library.Library_Story__c: I bought this LFL at a silent auction at the 2012 Decatur Book Festival. Each of the 12 LFLs being auctioned at that event was painted by a different local artist. Ours was done by David Laufer, who brought the concept to Georgia. It has a doorknow that says, "Welcome, Neighbor." He attended the inauguration event, which was held on our front porch. It was a special event for us because we had spent the preceding 25 years thinking a move to this walkable neighborhood was what we wanted. We finally did it, and this was our celebration gift to the neighborhood. There are now 6 LFLs within walking distance of ours.

I made my library out of an antique newspaper vending machine! It used to contain the Griffin Daily News. I painted it yellow and removed a lot of hardware. Then I stenciled all over it and had my family trace their hands on it. It's bright and colorful and catches the eye. Now I hope it becomes a vibrant book exchange!

On April 15, 2013, College Heights Early Child Learning Center in Decatur, Georgia, USA, held the unveiling ceremony for their own Little Free Library. The library is stocked with early childrenâ??s books (infant â?? Pre-K). The unveiling ceremony was a chance to build excitement around books and to launch our successful Books for Africa fundraiser which allowed us to donate a LFL to a community in Africa. The library has been a tremendous success, with children visiting daily on their way to and from school. The children are excited to swap books with each other. Our hope is to build a stronger sense of community as we share books with the College Heights community and with a community in Africa. At the unveiling, Mr. Matt led the children in the "Community Song" which includes the lyric "It's love that builds community." Matt Donald, "Mr.Matt", parent of Ethan, built and donated a Little Free Library to the Parent Teacher Association Silent Auction school fundraiser. Bill Dawson and Julie Carroll, parents of Charlotte, purchased the Little Free Library and donated it back to the school. Principal Suzanne Kennedy and School Librarian Karen Collins supported the LFL and helped organize the Books for Africa fundraiser. Karen Collins is the LFL steward.
library.Street__c:
College Heights Early Childhood Learning Center
917 S McDonough Street

library.Library_Story__c: Our family bid on this wonderful Little Library at our elementary school auction. All proceeds went to our school. Then our amazing neighbors all chipped in to make it our own Olympic Place Little Library. (Yes, there are a lot of "our"s in these sentences because it truly is a communal effort! Cabinets were donated by a nearby family, and Matt Donald made the Little Library (along with many others) and donated it to the school's auction. He came and installed it for us on Saturday, May 11th at 3 pm. Neighbors came to commemorate the Little Library and fill it with books. It's a wonderful sight to see people stopping to look at books, borrowing or giving. Our already strong community is even stronger through the sharing of stories, big and small.

Fred Armon Toomer Elementary School's community partner The Temple built installed and decorated 3 LFLs during their annual community service project on Mitzvah Day Sunday October 21 2012 for our entire school community. Everyone is invited to participate in our school community's book exchange and share the love of reading regardless if you are a Toomer Cougar Kirkwood Eastlake resident business owner or visiting the area. We appreciate everyone for helping us take care of our 3 LFLs and pay it forward by giving taking and sharing books for babies children and adults to enjoy from any genre. Our students are encouraged to visit the 3 LFLs with their teachers and families as often as possible. Thank you to everyone in the Kirkwood East Lake and any participating community business or civic group for helping us spread skills creativity and wisdom with our PreK through 5th grade students and across generations.
library.Street__c:
Fred Armon Toomer Elementary School
65 Rogers Street, NE

library.Library_Story__c: I live in a wonderful historic district just SW of Atlanta. I also live in a wonderful chalet lovingly named 'La Petite Maison de Joie'... The Little House of Joy. It's a happy house indeed...so much so - people will stop to say they go out of their way to drive by my house because it makes them happy. That's pretty darn cool if I do say so myself. I also LOVE BOOKS! I started Historic College Park Book Club HCPBookClub.com in 2007 with only 4 members and now we have over 40. We love to read and socialize with one another. It's a tight knit neighborhood - Historic College Park rocks!
Our Little Free Library allows us to combine our love of reading with our love of sharing with our neighbors and friends.

Our library came about from the inspiration of one, the collaborative hands of a family and a desire of a community. It is our hope that it encourages an exploration of ideas, places, people and worlds beyond our reach.

Our library is located at the home of the Ormewood Park Presbyterian Church and The Ormewood School. Our neighborhood's symbol is the trolley car and our library was designed with that in mind. The library was designed and created by Laine and Phil Proctor whose child attends the school. We love how unique it is and are excited to share it with all the folks who pass by it daily!
library.Street__c:
The Ormewood School
1071 Delaware Ave SE

library.Library_Story__c: Our box was built out of left over materials. The walls and floor are plywood and the roof an unknown material salvaged from set construction at the Fox Theater in Atlanta. The door is cherry with a patuk pull. The LL was filled up in two days after installation. We are located in an intown neighborhood near the Carter Center with lots of foot traffic.
Meet Gilbert beholder of all wisdom. Created straight from the imagination of husband and wife team BC2 Creations

library.Library_Name__c: Sanne and Chris Bagby #5619 Atlanta GA
library.Library_Story__c: Our library is named for our little cat Bo. It sports a sign reading "Bo's Books" and a comical likeness of him reading "Country Mouse City Mouse." Bo is well-known in our neighborhood and beloved by young and old. We thought the whimsy of naming our library after him would appeal to everyone. A sweet little green-robed figure - reading a book of his own - "lives" in the attic and watches over both the library and its users. note to admin: we have a blog going that is covering our LFL project from beginning to end. http://blog.woodworkingtooltips.com/2013/03/the-little-free-library-where-woodworking-and-reading-can-be-shared-with-the-community/

Our little library is in existence because of our love of books. I am an elementary school teacher and my husband is a librarian. My favorite part of teaching fifth grade is helping students discover their next favorite book or author. We are also very lucky because my childhood best friend is an illustrator. Tatyana Feeney decorated our library with characters from her books: Small Bunny's Blue Blanket and Little Owl's Orange Scarf. I will keep the library stocked with great children's books from middle grades to picture books but we also have great adult choices too. I hope that I can help even more people develop a passion for reading beyond my classroom. You can visit our Facebook page and make requests or comment. Our goal is to help everyone find a new favorite book! https://www.facebook.com/CorinnesLittleFreeLibrary
This was a father (Chris) and daughter (Fiona) project during Labor Day 2012.

When we heard about the Little Free Library movement, we were so excited that we had to build out own. We put our library up this morning and within a few hours, some kids in our neighborhood had already borrowed and donated books! We can't wait to see how this little library will bring our community together!

This Little Free Library is hand built and hand painted by Scot and Emily- who have no construction experience at all! There are tons of dog walkers and kids in our neighborhood and we wanted to start sharing our love of books with the rest. It is also the first Little Free Library in our neighborhood- East Atlanta Village.

It's an old metal newspaper box that has been deconstructed and rebuilt for a library box. Recycled steel pipes and other parts help make the junk-yard look. A circus sign invites people to take a look. An old letterpress printing press is visible in the background.

LFL #3116 is located in the historic neighborhood of Candler Park in Atlanta. Candler Park is an eclectic intown community with many craftsman bungalows from the early 1900's. We learned about the Little Free Library from the Decatur Book Festival. We love seeing our neighbors and passersby browse, take and share books. Thanks for sharing this great idea.

Fred Armon Toomer Elementary School's community partner The Temple built installed and decorated 3 LFLs during their annual community service project on Mitzvah Day Sunday October 21 2012 for our entire school community. Everyone is invited to participate in our school community's book exchange and share the love of reading regardless if you are a Toomer Cougar Kirkwood Eastlake resident business owner or visiting the area. We appreciate everyone for helping us take care of our 3 LFLs and pay it forward by giving taking and sharing books for babies children and adults to enjoy from any genre. Our students are encouraged to visit the 3 LFLs with their teachers and families as often as possible. Thank you to everyone in the Kirkwood East Lake and any participating community business or civic group for helping us spread skills creativity and wisdom with our PreK through 5th grade students and across generations.

I have always loved to read and one of my favorite things to do is share good books with the people I love. When I found out about the Little Free Library program I knew there was no question that I needed to participate. My boyfriend's father is fantastic with tools and he built my library for Christmas this year (2012). I am dedicating my library to my grandmother who passed away very suddenly before Thanksgiving this year. She was an avid reader and was always so supportive of education. She loved the idea of the Little Free Library. I hope to keep a varied collection of books in my library--mostly adult fiction with a nice selection of children's books too. A lot of the books I have read but I hope people will leave books they have loved as well.

For a long time we worked at a daily newspaper. Our livelihood depended on readers. The newspaper business cut back on reporters and we are doing other work now. Reading will always be important in our family and so will journalism. Our Little Free Library encourages reading of all kinds. In 2012 my column about the auction of Little Free Libraries at the Decatur Book Festival inspired us to repurpose this newspaper box for this first LFL in our Decatur neighborhood of Clairmont Heights. http://saportareport.com/blog/2012/08/atlanta-little-free-libraries/

The library was made with all reused materials except the Plexiglas window and some hardware. The back wall is futon slats glued to a thin board; the sides are repurposed cabinet doors; the handle is from an old faucet; the shingles were left over from my first roof (was that 30 years ago?); ridge cover is some random piece of plastic; and the paint was from Lowes returned items. The perch on the left was to try to encourage the birds to land (and poop) there instead of on the roof itself, but it doesn't seem to be working.
This LFL is a tribute to the Plaza Theatre in Atlanta. It opened in 1939 and has been a favorite of moviegoers for decades.

Fred Armon Toomer Elementary School's community partner The Temple built installed and decorated 3 LFLs during their annual community service project on Mitzvah Day Sunday October 21 2012 for our entire school community. Everyone is invited to participate in our school community's book exchange and share the love of reading regardless if you are a Toomer Cougar Kirkwood Eastlake resident business owner or visiting the area. We appreciate everyone for helping us take care of our 3 LFLs and pay it forward by giving taking and sharing books for babies children and adults to enjoy from any genre. Our students are encouraged to visit the 3 LFLs with their teachers and families as often as possible. Thank you to everyone in the Kirkwood East Lake and any participating community business or civic group for helping us spread skills creativity and wisdom with our PreK through 5th grade students and across generations.

Andrew's parents built this library for us as a gift for his 25th birthday. They built it out of scraps from around their house and a few from their neighbors.  Is has two stories of book shelves and a window to browse through the books on the upper shelf.

library.Street__c: 1500 Davis Oaks way Corner of Lavista and Alderbrook

library.Library_Story__c: We had a neighborhood welcoming party!
